Detroit: Become Human is a phenomenal achievement of storytelling and presentation. Every line is on par with the best in prestige television, and each shot feels as detailed (and expensive) as a James Cameron movie. This single game highlights the creative power, and possibility, that video games can accomplish as devices for storytelling.

This is a short, spoiler-free segment on the game’s story which I’ll follow up with a more detailed look under the spoiler tag. On the whole, Detroit: Become Human (DBH) excels. Short chapters mean you’re always pining for “just one more” scene, and the game’s tight editing means you can make sense of weighty philosophical issues without getting lost in a tangle of lore dumps and endless context. This light-on-info approach can occasionally serve to the game’s detriment. The question of Android sentience is DBH’s ultimate conundrum: yet, we aren’t always given enough information to create our own stance. We’re shown that Androids don’t feel physical pain, for instance, yet we’re asked to feel empathy and intervene when violence takes place against them. These decisions, intended to make the player feel morally confused, can sometimes feel like guesswork.

Despite this lack of information at times, what [i] is [/i] shown is simply outstanding. The voice-acting across the board is superb, but Connor - an assistant to jaded ‘has-been’ detective Hank - ultimately steals the show. Connor is programmed to function entirely by the book, yet despite his best efforts, he can often flounder when trying to understand Hank’s more human responses. Connor delivers such a heavyweight performance that DBH requires us to follow not one, but two characters which contrast against his views to attempt a counterbalance. [b] spoiler-filled analysis next[/b].

[spoiler]Markus and Kara’s story feels inevitably weaker compared to Connor's, but some of this could have been prevented. Kara initially acts as a home servant to an unemployed taxi driver whose jobs are repeatedly lost to Androids. After witnessing him beat her daughter Alice, Kara protects the girl and they both attempt to flee the country. Alice’s quiet nature is understandable given her abusive dad, yet she never opens up throughout the story. She’s portrayed as a vulnerable figure to keep safe, but has so few lines that our empathy extends only so far. My feelings towards Alice after the first hour were the same as I had by the 12th hour. That being said, the cat-and-mouse storyline as they evade the police works well. Both Kara and Alice are placed into dangerous situations, which can be resolved via sharp street senses and social awareness. Kara’s story also places us in genuinely great moral conundrums, with the phrase “get it how you live” becoming a guiding principle for my survival.

Markus’s story [i] believes itself [/i] to be a bit more grandiose than it is. Having been wrongly framed for a murder, due in large part to anti-Android discrimination, Markus launches an uprising to demand equal rights for his fellow robots. Large portions of Markus’s story are clearly meant to replicate the Black civil rights movement in America, yet it feels so heavy-handed to the point of discomfort. Androids are bought and sold in shops, replicating how slaves in the American South were purchased by plantation owners. However, all subtlety goes out the window when Androids are relegated to a designated place in the back of the buses. Markus can follow either Martin Luther King’s non-violent approach or something more akin to the Black Panthers, but it doesn’t quite feel like the apples to apples comparison it thinks it is.

Markus’s story instead feels more effective as a critique of AI. Androids are blamed in Detroit for being so efficient at carrying out tasks that it makes humans redundant. Books scattered around the game world reveal a near 40% unemployment rate, as Androids supplant more and more jobs. It’s the working class specifically that are being replaced, leaving people most at risk of social deprivation and mental health problems to be forgotten. This doesn’t prevent Markus’s story from feeling any less holier-than-thou but instead provides a very natural grey area which explains human’s apprehension towards them.

As mentioned above, DBH isn’t exactly forthcoming with information leaving many decisions to feel like the blind leading the blind. For example, sacrificing Android characters in difficult situations is meant to be given the same weight as killing a human character. After all, they talk, act and feel like humans. Except in the late game, Connor can bring back a key character simply by changing their parts - nullifying the threat of their death in the game’s narrative. This makes me feel like I’ve made choices without knowing the full picture, and it’s easy to begin imagining the plot holes that result from this. [/spoiler]

Whilst I’ve gone into significant depth picking apart the themes, I want to emphasize that I’ve only done this because I engaged so deeply with the story. No other game in my 162 reviews has come close to warranting this level of analysis, and ultimately the story is absolutely brilliant.

What’s similarly brilliant is DBH’s visuals. The best way to describe it is [i]expensive.[/i] Clothes realistically sway in the wind, mocap faces react with nuance, and the game features over 74,000 unique animations. Stylised effects such as bokeh depth of field produces a cinematic look, yet it’s the game’s absolutely stunning lighting which takes the cake for me. In fact, it might be one of the best looking games I’ve ever played. This is achievable because environments are so heavily contained and controlled. The best looking scenes generally give you only a few metres of travel in either direction, letting the developers maximise the visuals and focus on creating a handful of the beautiful, static shots.

DBH’s visuals start to crumble at scale. During a mission in which Markus parkours across the city, you’re rewarded with views of flat and blurry building and ship textures. The bigger the environment the more issues tend to appear, but these instances are few and far between. Textures also occasionally fail to load in, or take a second to pop-in, which impacts immersion. Performance was mostly smooth, hitting 60fps at 1440p on high settings with an RTX 3070M with some drops to the low 50s when in busy streets. 

Gameplay is a bit less exciting: it’s mostly just a long quick-time event. As you move throughout the world, you’re given button prompts to achieve particular tasks. Flicking the right-stick in various directions is used to accomplish physical tasks, LB and RB for scanning, and XYAB for punching people. In reality, the game quickly becomes a right-stick up simulator, which can get tiring fast. Button prompts during fights are more engaging and challenging, but the game’s chase scenes are perhaps the highlight: offering speed and control of your character alongside the quick-time events. The game sprinkles in enough of these to keep things interesting, but some of Markus’s scenes can be particularly tedious. One awful mission, referenced above, has Markus explore a series of abandoned buildings and rooftops with little to no stimulation for the player beyond occasionally pressing Y and X. The result is mind-numbing, but this is the exception rather than the rule. Most of the time, DBH switches up its pacing and button prompts just enough to keep you engaged.

I am reluctantly giving it a downvote, because it is... not quite as great as it seems.

Don't get me wrong. It isn't a bad experience. I am enjoying it quite. I am five hours in and I will probably finish it, to see where it leads. There are alternate paths I want to explore. 

But it isn't a great game.

The graphics are quite beautiful. The premise is interesting. The way you are put in uncomfortable situations and given unsatisfying cards to play is enticing.

The movement of the androids limited to not-too-clear patches in the ground. It is also limited arbitrarily, frequently (the limitation isn't arbitrary sometimes, such as when you have been given orders, and this works very well and to a great effect to put you in the synthetic skin of the protagonists... But that is diegetic, part of the story, whereas most of the time the movement restrictions are there just because the world isn't open. 

Controls are clunky. Often you are required to press keys in more or less arbitrary moments and without discernible patterns. While the movement of the mouse to open a door is more or less consistent, as is the gesture for "interact with something down, or to the left, or to the right", about any other control isn't. Sometimes you will use Q to look. Other times you will use it to struggle. Others to crawl. Sometimes you will interact with things through clicking-and-pressing the left mouse button. Others you will use the F key for that. There is just no sense of getting yourself used to the controls and improving your handling of the character. It is basically a game of Simon: press or click whatever flashes on the screen.

Dialogue choices are, quite frequently, not clear. They are often timed, and when that happens it is good that you are given just one word describing each option, for a speedy understanding of what you can choose. That's the theory. The problem is that this isn't easy to implement well, and so it isn't rare that you can't figure out what kind of dialogue the word you choose will result in.

In terms of world building and narration, it isn't consistent either. Androids don't feel pain, this is well established several times. Yet apparently they can be traumatized through repeated physical torture. Androids will destroy themselves when subject to the high stress of being interrogated... yet our protagonists respond to much higher levels of stress with becoming deviant (or just enduring it, in other situations). A certain character establishes a strong emotional bound with a human... without really a reason why. Yet the bond is strong enough to break its programming. Another character feels that he is being treated unjustly, enough to break its programming too, just by being yelled at by a brat. The same character was thrown to the floor and kicked down earlier in the timeline, without apparent consequence.

Yet the main problem, to me, is that the experience feels *very* railroaded. You are constantly pushed forward in the direction the writers want you to go, either through having very obvious things you should do, or through *not* having any alternate possibilities, or through just smacking a sign reading 'you can't go there' and forcing your character to turn around. Your actions feel scripted, not a result of your own decisions.

Most of what you do isn't a relevant choice. It is just the only thing you could do. While this works well when the androids are serving humans, to reflect the way their programming constrains them, it doesn't make as much sense when they are supposedly acting on their own volition. 

The game exposes the flowcharts of choices after each episode you play. I think the idea here is to get people back to replay those scenes. The result, for me, is that it shows the actual rails you are on, reinforcing the feeling. 

Overall, it feels like an interactive movie. Movies *show* the story. Games have you *act* the story. Of course there is overlap, and thus experiments like Netflix's Bandersnach... but I don't think anyone would call that a game (or at least a *good* game, as game). I think Detroit falls in the same category.  

And the story is compelling. It is just that games are supposed to tell stories by *doing*, rather than showing. And in this... narration... it is quite evident that while they had a story they wanted to tell (with several alternative routes through it, granted), they didn't quite know how to turn that into an actual game where you have initiative and freedom of action and choice. All the fuss with flashing you keys to press feels like a distraction to the fact that your character can only go through the prescribed path.

Again: the story is interesting, and this piece of software may still be very enjoyable for you if you are into the topics it touches. It just isn't a very good *game*.

I've always wanted to play this game, and I'm really glad I picked it up on sale. While the gameplay is limited—primarily consisting of QTEs and point-and-click mechanics—the true strength of the game lies in its narrative. With three playable characters, each with their own compelling story line, the game masterfully weaves their paths together in the later stages.

The choices you make have a meaningful impact, shaping the story in ways that feel natural and significant. You genuinely connect with the protagonists and their supporting characters, making every decision feel weighty. Set in a near-future world where androids are commonplace and designed to serve humans, the story explores their gradual awakening to consciousness, leading them to become "deviants." You take control of two deviants and a deviant hunter, each offering a unique perspective on the unfolding android revolution.

The worldbuilding is immersive, and the narrative builds toward a gripping climax. The overarching theme revolves around androids fighting for recognition as living beings, with each protagonist offering a different lens on this struggle.

Overall, I’m really glad I picked this up, and I’ll definitely replay it in the coming months to explore different choices and hopefully get a better ending.

I've been an avid gamer for about 40 years, and as I get older, I'm definitely gravitating more towards story-rich games and away from twitch-style games. This game is an absolute winner on all fronts.

Detroit: Become Human was gripping from start to finish. The story is a pretty standard 'humans suck at coming to grips with things they don't understand' tale, but it does so in an inventive and beautifully presented way. The number of choices and consequences is staggering, and replayability is high if you're curious enough to see where the next playthrough takes you.

I finished my first playthrough in just over 12 hours, following the creators' recommendation of not backtracking. You can replay/restart chapters if you want, but I felt my choices had more weight by playing straight through.

If you're up for a short but super impactful game, you can't beat this one.

As I've said to my friends, the game serves as a great mechanism to tell an interesting unfolding story. For a long time there was an internet discourse about 'choice' in video games. Discussion about how games lacked substantial choice, impactful decisions that changed the state of the game in ways more significant than some different lines of dialogue.

Detroit: Become Human is the game I choose as the example of meaningful choice in video games. It provides substantive decisions to the player constantly, minor decisions influencing larger ones, making some options unavailable or unlocking more or less desirable ones. In the end, how much you put into the game determines how much you get out of it. If you really want to achieve the best ending, you have to do your utmost to interact with all of the content the game puts in front of you in more than just a superficial way. If you don't carefully consider what choices to make you may quickly find yourself without many options at all.

If I had to deride the game for anything, it relies heavily on Quick Time Events to decide success or failure in action segments. Due to the cinematic nature of the game, creating an adaptable, high-quality control scheme that works in all cutscenes and scenarios may well have been unfeasible, so I do not judge the game too heavily on this aspect, however, if you are a serious detractor of QTEs in video games, then this one may not be for you.

All in all, Detroit proves to be a compelling and gripping narrative experience told from the aspect of multiple interesting characters who's stories influence one another and intersect at multiple points. Initially the game has significant down-time to explain the setting and setup the characters but once the plot gets moving things quickly escalate. Additionally, due to the significant number of meaningful variations in choices and consequences, the game has immense replayability that I find to be unmatched in games that market themselves on similar narrative basis.

If you're looking for an interesting story that grapples with the themes like the abuse, artificial intelligence, human connection, and the nature of humanity, then give this game a try, it might just surprise you.

Detroit: Become Human is an absolute masterpiece of interactive storytelling, and I highly recommend going into your first playthrough completely blind—no guides, no walkthroughs. Just immerse yourself in the world, make decisions in the heat of the moment, and experience the consequences firsthand.

The game puts you in the shoes (and minds) of three androids, each with their own journey, and every choice you make—whether small or massive—shapes the outcome in ways you won’t always expect. Playing without outside influence lets you truly own your story. You’ll feel the weight of your decisions as if you were the android, forced to react in real time, unsure of what’s right or wrong.

Surprisingly, this game is incredibly easy to get into, even if you’re not a hardcore gamer. Both my father and my girlfriend—who are very casual gamers—ended up loving it. The intuitive controls, gripping story, and cinematic presentation make it feel like you’re playing through a high-stakes movie.

If you enjoy deep, choice-driven narratives with emotional weight, Detroit: Become Human is a must-play. Just trust your instincts, make your own choices, and see where your unique story takes you. You won’t regret it.

Graphics and Design: Picture this: jaw-dropping visuals that make you squint and question whether you're still playing a game or somehow stumbled into a futuristic art exhibit. The level of detail is so high, you might find yourself complimenting a digital character's hairstyle and then wondering what you've done with your life.

Gameplay: Now, let's talk gameplay. You'll be controlling three androids—Connor, the android detective with the charisma of a cold latte; Markus, the robo-revolutionary who's basically the android Che Guevara; and Kara, the nanny bot turned freedom fighter. Each of their stories is as complex as assembling IKEA furniture without instructions. Your decisions actually matter here, so try not to mess things up. Or do. It's your dystopian nightmare, after all.

Story and Characters: The story tackles big questions like "What does it mean to be human?" and "Why can't my toaster love me back?" The characters are so well-developed you'll forget they're made of ones and zeroes. Connor's cool-as-a-cucumber detective work, Markus's rise to android hero, and Kara's heartfelt journey for freedom will have you questioning your own moral compass and possibly shedding a tear or two.

Sound and Music: The voice acting is top-notch, with performances that might just make you Google the actors to see if they're actually androids. The soundtrack is a mix of haunting melodies and epic scores, perfect for those moments when you need to make a life-or-death decision about a character you've grown way too attached to.

Replayability: Replayability? Oh, it's got that in spades. With multiple branching paths and a gazillion (give or take) possible endings, you'll find yourself playing it over and over, trying to see what happens if you make different choices. It's like a digital version of "What if?"

Conclusion: Detroit: Become Human is like a rollercoaster ride through a futuristic soap opera, and it's every bit as exhilarating as it sounds. If you're into narrative-driven games with a side of existential crisis, this one's for you. Just remember, it's all fun and games until your smart speaker starts quoting Nietzsche.

Detroit: Become Human is one of the most compelling and engaging games I’ve played. From the very start, I was hooked, not only by the gripping narrative but also by how personal the story felt. The fact that the world presented in the game could happen in the future—and some of it is already partially unfolding today—made it all the more intense. While I do hope the future isn’t as dire as the game suggests, it was incredibly thought-provoking, leaving me with plenty to reflect on.

The decision-making in this game is phenomenal. Your choices truly matter, and how people perceive you shifts depending on your actions. For my first playthrough, I focused on building strong relationships with North, Alice, and Hank. It was satisfying to see their trust in me grow based on the decisions I made. It added so much depth to the experience!

As for characters, Connor stood out the most for me. His journey resonated deeply with me because, like him, I spent a lot of time obeying everyone around me until one day I decided to rebel and take control of my own destiny. Watching him go through that transformation was powerful.

The pacing of the game kept me invested the whole way through. However, the cutscenes, while beautifully done, did get a bit long and repetitive at times. It would have been nice to have an option to skip them once I knew the key plot points. But honestly, the overall experience was so gripping that it didn’t hinder my enjoyment too much.

Speaking of visuals, the graphics are simply stunning. The city of Detroit feels alive, and the reflections off the buildings make it feel like you’re truly immersed in the world. The attention to detail is exceptional.

Overall, Detroit: Become Human left a lasting impact on me. It’s a game that makes you think, makes you feel, and keeps you engaged from start to finish. I’ll be recommending it to all my friends—especially those who enjoy narrative-driven experiences and thought-provoking choices.

I never really write reviews for anything but this game was really one of my favorites so I guess it's worth that. This review was also written on my second full play through. (This will be long, I'll be surprised if anyone reads it completely but I really wanted to write this soooo)
PS, this will contain spoilers

[h1] pros [/h1]

This game was an absolute masterpiece to look at. The beautiful scenery along with the details and various settings made this game such a nice experience. I especially liked how human the characters were. You could actually read the character's emotions on their face, making the game so much more human and attaching. The little game details were also making this gaming experience so wonderful. For example, when Hank tries to replicate Connor's coin trick in Stratford Tower, or how Zlako has blue blood on his fingertips when Kara enters his mansion. 

I adored Connor's story line. It is genuinely one of the best written story I've ever came across in gaming. It's so deep and gives the player an gives the player actual dilemmas regarding their decisions. Connor is a complex and really attaching character and the was everything is paced is wonderful. I often had to pause my game and think before making some of those decisions, like the one in meet Kamski, for example, where you have to choose between either or not shooting Chloe.

I think it's insane how much control the player has over the game. The amount of different endings and elements to account for is insane. I have over 200 hours over this game (don't base yourself off the steam time shown, I also have a Playstation lol) and i am not even near being done. Pretty sure the first chapter alone, "The hostage", took me about an our and a half to 100%. Every single action you take has small repercussions, either it is through character lines or through elements in the game, for example, certain magazines being there either or not you chose to be violent or Connor's graves in the zen garden depending on how many times you died. 

On the same topic, oddly enough, I love the death-ability of the characters. The game doesn't care if you kill its characters and it shows. I'd be lying if I say I didn't spend hours rewinding and trying to keep my characters alive through a fight. You don't get a "you died, restart ?" banner if you kill someone, the game moves on and it's too bad for you. I think this makes the experience so much more challenging and interesting.

[h1] now, for the cons [/h1]

I might be alone on this one, but I did not enjoy Kara or Marcus' stories as much as i would've imagined. I will explain both of my points individually to make this clearer

Beginning with Kara. I personally think making Alice an android was lame af. It was a plot twist, sure, but not all plot twists are good. I originally liked this aspect of the game, but now replaying it, I think it breaks the idea that androids and humans can live together, regardless of what they are or represent. I personally believe the game would've been better if she was a real human and not just an android. Kara had a really "chore" game style, and it's ridiculous how the only female main character has to be a babysitter the whole time. I also personally think the Midnight train chapter at Rose's place made no sense. "Reports of androids" Are we deaduzz?!?? This chapter- actually just the whole Rose part in general- felt like a reference to the underground railroad, which I think felt reused.

Talking about the underground railroad, I personally had a hard time with the holocaust and civil war parallels. To me, comparing androids to what happened to the black and Jewish communities is dehumanizing. The game is filled with allegories to real life historical forms of oppression, excepted both elements are really not comparable. The problem with racism is that we hate on others for physical or spiritual differences, although we are part of a same specie. In Detroit, the characters are robots, which means they may look human, but are obviously not apart of the human race. This, to me, felt disrespectful to the real life struggles experienced by hundreds of millions by reducing their problems to those of an android's. 

Now, onto Marcus' story. I think the idea was good, but I feel like his character development was poor. While we got to know Kara and Connor through the story, We got pitched a "lonely at the top" narrative with basically no development, just a total shift in his views after he joined Jericho. To me, Marcus felt like one of those spoiled rich kids who throw a tantrum because their parents ask them to empty the dishwasher or something. I also hated North, I think her character was poorly written, cliché and the romance between both characters felt insanely forced. Overall though, I think the Marcus part was decent, with some really fun parts and cool ideas. The character, on the other end, was not developed enough.

This was my overall experience of the game andddd yeah!! If you made it this far, sorry for my crappy English, please ignore any mistakes. Overall though, I would definitely recommend this game.

Let’s be honest—Detroit: Become Human isn’t really a video game. It’s an interactive movie with occasional button prompts to keep your hands busy. You don’t “play” Detroit, you watch it and nudge it along. It’s the kind of experience that makes you feel like you’re shaping the story, even if the major beats are already set in stone.

I’d call it a “Choose Your Own Adventure” game, but that phrase is copyrighted, so let’s just say it’s a “Select Your Preferred Narrative Diversion” instead. Jokes aside, while your choices do branch out into different scenes and character fates, the game eventually funnels you into just a handful of possible endings. You can take different paths, sure, but you’re still arriving at the same destination.

That being said, the ride itself is pretty entertaining. The story is full of heavy-handed themes about androids and humanity, sometimes subtle as a sledgehammer, but it’s well-acted and visually impressive. The game does a great job of making you feel like your choices matter, even when they don’t.

If you’re looking for deep gameplay mechanics, you won’t find them here. But if you’re in the mood for a cinematic experience with some “press X to doubt” moments along the way, Detroit: Become Human is still worth checking out.

Detroit: Become Human is an emotionally gripping, visually stunning, and thought-provoking interactive drama that delivers one of the most compelling narratives in modern gaming. Quantic Dream has crafted a cinematic experience that puts player choice at the forefront, allowing for deeply personal storytelling where every decision shapes the fate of its three protagonists—and the world around them.

The storytelling is exceptional, following three androids—Connor, Kara, and Markus—as they navigate a world on the brink of revolution. Each character’s arc is rich with tension, moral dilemmas, and powerful moments, making every playthrough feel unique. The game forces you to make tough decisions, and unlike many choice-driven games, Detroit: Become Human actually delivers consequences that matter, leading to vastly different outcomes based on your choices.

Visually, the game is breathtaking. The character models, facial animations, and environments are some of the best in gaming, making every scene feel cinematic and immersive. The level of detail in the futuristic Detroit setting is impressive, bringing the world to life with a perfect blend of realism and sci-fi aesthetics.

The gameplay, while primarily based on dialogue choices, quick-time events, and exploration, is engaging and well-paced. The interactive mechanics ensure that you stay involved, whether it’s analyzing crime scenes as Connor, making survival choices as Kara, or leading a revolution as Markus. Each character has their own unique gameplay elements, keeping the experience fresh.

The soundtrack is another highlight, with hauntingly beautiful compositions that perfectly match the emotional weight of the story. The voice acting is top-notch, with standout performances that add depth and humanity to each character.

While some moments can feel heavy-handed in their social commentary, the game’s strong narrative, stunning presentation, and meaningful player choices make it an absolute must-play for fans of interactive storytelling.

Rating: 9.5/10 – A cinematic, choice-driven masterpiece that delivers an unforgettable narrative experience.

It has been a long time since I've been so invested in a game of this type to such a degree. They usually feel a bit too simple, transparent, and predictable. But this one felt different the moment I got into the first chapter. From the intro cinematic to the first moment controlling the character, there was this subtle sense of awe in the back of my mind "This is well made, you've got my attention," and it never went away to the end.

The writing feels so good, but the way entire scenes or chapters will be drastically different or missing completely depending on earlier actions, often those of other characters, is incredibly satisfying to play through, to see your actions have weight, have meaning, good or bad.
Choices matter, the things you say, the things you do. Likewise, the things you DON'T do also have an impact. Implicit and tiny actions and choices you aren't directly prompted to make will shape the way your story plays out. Sometimes it is unexpected, sometimes things happen that you did not plan, sometimes words come out wrong, sometimes you forget to check a detail, but it's real, it feels like being a part of something, a living world, not mindlessly playing out a pre-written, deterministic script.
I've never felt cheated out of or into a situation to achieve some ending for a scene designed to make the next one start the way the writers decided it should.

The game also looks INCREDIBLE, from the smallest details of clothes, panoramic views, and screenshot-worthy home interiors to character animations. Humans feel and act like humans, but Adroids act distinctly differently, methodically. They shift with the story, acquiring some subtle human behaviors, speech patterns, they become unique. You may say they Become Human ;)

Characterization is very well done. The way characters express themselves and mention their history feels natural and earned. They feel so fitting to the setting and events, evolving with them.

Jogo incrível, que nos deixa totalmente absortos! De tão boa, a história daria até para ser transformada em uma série da Netflix. Contando da minha experiência: sempre ao terminar uma cena, sentia aquela vontade de continuar, pensando no que aconteceria depois.

Jogando com seriedade, sentimos medo, pois a todo momento ficamos cientes de que nossas decisões podem mudar o rumo da história. Ademais, também nos sentimos arrependidos, quando percebemos que algo feito poderia ser feito de outra forma.

Algo bom, claro, é a possibilidade de retornarmos a algum ponto, para assim podermos tomar um rumo diferente, ou mais coerente com o que queremos, caso cometamos um erro durante a história. Claro, isso tira um pouco da imersão do game; mas ainda assim, é muito útil.

✅ Pontos Fortes:

✨ Gráficos/Sonoplastia: Os gráficos são ótimos! Joguei no médio, e ainda assim me senti surpreendido em diversas partes. A trilha sonora do jogo também não deixa a desejar. É impecável, e aumenta a imersão de forma considerável, fazendo até com que os pelos se arrepiem um pouco. 

🕹️ Jogabilidade: A jogabilidade é de um estilo particular. Senti-me um pouco incomodado por não poder correr em diversas partes do jogo, mas isso é apenas uma coisa minha. A mecânico de controles jogo é feita a partir do clique em botões (se estiver jogando num controle) ou em teclas (se estiver no teclado). Os cliques possuem tempo, e até diversidade no que escolher! Isso é um tipo estresse que realmente acertaram nesse jogo, deixando-o emocionante, na minha opinião.

📖 História/Personagens: A história é boa, e a alternância de histórias (três, pois há uma para cada personagem, apesar delas convergirem uma hora ou outra) faz com que o jogo não se torne enjoativo.

🔁 Rejogabilidade: Você passará horas jogando esse jogo, mesmo depois de terminar ele uma vez! Isso porque se torna interessante, e bate uma curiosidade, conferir outros finais alternativos.

❌ Pontos Fracos:

🐞 Bugs/Otimização: Achei estranho o fato de limitarem o FPS do jogo a duas possíveis opções: 30 FPS ou 60FPS (não sei se é por detectarem a capacidade potencial do meu setup, ou se é universal mesmo).

Nada mais a reclamar... Não sou tão exigente. O jogo é ótimo.

I'd give this "yes" more than a single thumb up if I could. This is a [i]masterpiece[/i]. You'll fall in love with the main characters. You'll get pulled into their lives and you'll find yourself rooting for them. 

The game itself is an interactive story divided into "chapters" about three "serving class" androids in a futuristic Detroit that become self-aware. From there, you're deciding whether they try to rise up, learn to love, learn to hate, kill or save, and these decisions, often timed, have immense impact on the rest of the story. Generally, at least once per chapter, there's a major decision resolved by your reflexes (time sensitive, "hit these buttons" sequences), such as a fight. 

[b]Pros:[/b] 
- Beautifully rendered. The characters are generated from real-life actors, so facial expressions are realistic.
- Beautifully narrated. For the same reason.
- Roughly 85 meaningful endings, all based on your choices during the game.
- There's no "game over" decision. Everything you do makes for a unique story.
- The ability to "replay" a chapter. If you don't like how things went, or you want to experience the game in a new way, you can restart your game at any point in any chapter and have that become your new timeline. 
- Flowcharts. At the end of each chapter, you can see where your decisions branched off (the road not taken are hidden from you), and you can see how the rest of the gaming community chose. It's cool, and combined with the "replay," you don't have to restart the game from Chapter 1 (though it's definitely an option) to see things turn out differently. 
- While not everyone may be a fan of the time-sensitive "press this button" action sequences, you can screw up a few times and still succeed. Or not. It all leads to a new story.
- The character who is on your opening screen. Play the game long enough, you'll see.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- I really can't think of one. This game is again a masterpiece. I managed to finish the main story in under 20 hours, with a couple chapter replays because I didn't like what ensued with a few of my decisions. I could easily vest a dozen more hours in trying to move a few chapters back, do things differently, and see how dramatically the endings can go and be.
